awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of Fire-Safe and Low-Cost Flow Batteries using New Membranes for Long-Duration Energy Storage
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is derived from providing energy self-sufficiency to residential buildings. Fire-safe and low-cost redox flow batteries, combined with rooftop solar panels or backyard wind turbines, can meet the increased electricity needs of American families without relying on the national grid. During the daytime, solar arrays convert solar energy to chemical energy in batteries. During evenings, batteries will power houses and charge electric vehicles in family garages. Batteries play a critical role in harvesting and storing clean electricity for residential uses. Compared with lithium-ion batteries, the improved fire-safety profiles and reduced production costs of flow batteries will give homeowners peace of mind and allow the wider adoption of clean energy by society.

This SBIR phase I project proposes to develop novel proton-conductive polymeric membranes that show reduced metal electrolyte crossovers and build the first 7 kW flow battery system that meets the energy need of a single-family house. To this end, the project will synthesize a group of phosphorylated polybenzimidazoles (PBIs) that have a phosphoric acid side chain. Such phosphoric acid groups can form unique zirconium phosphonate clusters that transport protons but deny the unwanted migration of metal cations. PBIs provide mechanical support to the zirconium-phosphate clusters. Zirconium and PBIs are bulk materials that cost significantly less than commercial perfluorosulfonic acids. The second task of this phase I project is to construct a 7 kW iron-titanium redox flow battery system. The peak electricity demand for the average American single-family house is around 7 kW. Such a battery will be connected to a rooftop solar system to meet residential electricity demands. The team plans to study various cell configuration designs. In particular, the project will focus on examining the effects of solvent channels of bipolar plates on the performance of the stack. In addition, other design parameters, such as pump flow rates and the choice of sealant materials, will be thoroughly investigated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Energao, Inc. develops fire-safe and low-cost redox flow batteries for long-duration energy storage. After being integrated with rooftop solar, our batteries supply power to consumer households when the grid is unavailable due to natural disasters or other reasons, helping build a resilient community. Compared to lithium batteries currently on the market, our batteries are fire-safe, cheaper, and last longer. One special advantage over Lithium battery is: during a long period of rainy season, when there is not enough sun light to charge the battery, a Lithium-ion battery would be dead, but we can physically replace the energy storage tanks to ensure power is available to the user. An off-grid house is possible by using our batteries integrated with solar panels. 

 

As a result of our phase I grant from NSF, extensive research has been done in the following areas: 

  1. The performance of two different Redox systems is optimize, one in acidic conditions, another in neutral to weak basic conditions. Two major improvements were achieved on this topic: first, activating porous carbon electrode through chemical and thermal treatment significantly increases catalytic efficiency. Cell performance in power output density increases by two and a half times after treatment. Second, the composition of supporting electrolytes is also important to improve the power density of the cell output by increasing the solubility of active electrolytes. For the acidic system, the difference in power density reaches 1.8-fold while using a combination of two different supporting electrolytes compared with an individual supporting electrolyte. 

  2. A novel proton-conductive composite polymer membrane is studied. Compared to the industrial standard Nafion membrane, our membrane is designed to reduce ion crossover significantly, which helps improve the long-term stability of the battery. 

  3. The flow pattern of the manifold and flow channels on the reaction area was carefully studied and designed to ensure that electrolytes are introduced to the electrodes evenly across the cell and are in good contact with the electrodes. Consideration was put in place to achieve even flow by controlling the pressure drop and minimizing the shunt current. Various flow channel designs were carried out, and the graphite plates with these alternative flow channels were tested for their effects on pressure drops and cell performance.  

  4. A new power control system (a cell phone App) was designed for remote access to the battery. Consumers can monitor battery health and energy consumption using the app. The app also communicates with a server if any concern about battery health is raised. 


Last Modified: 04/18/2025
Modified by: Rong Jiang
por.por_txt_cntn:
Energao, Inc. develops fire-safe and low-cost redox flow batteries for long-duration energy storage. After being integrated with rooftop solar, our batteries supply power to consumer households when the grid is unavailable due to natural disasters or other reasons, helping build a resilient community. Compared to lithium batteries currently on the market, our batteries are fire-safe, cheaper, and last longer. One special advantage over Lithium battery is: during a long period of rainy season, when there is not enough sun light to charge the battery, a Lithium-ion battery would be dead, but we can physically replace the energy storage tanks to ensure power is available to the user. An off-grid house is possible by using our batteries integrated with solar panels.









As a result of our phase I grant from NSF, extensive research has been done in the following areas:





The performance of two different Redox systems is optimize, one in acidic conditions, another in neutral to weak basic conditions. Two major improvements were achieved on this topic: first, activating porous carbon electrode through chemical and thermal treatment significantly increases catalytic efficiency. Cell performance in power output density increases by two and a half times after treatment. Second, the composition of supporting electrolytes is also important to improve the power density of the cell output by increasing the solubility of active electrolytes.For the acidic system, the difference in power density reaches 1.8-fold while using a combination of two different supporting electrolytes compared with an individual supporting electrolyte.




A novel proton-conductive composite polymer membrane is studied. Compared to the industrial standard Nafion membrane, our membrane is designed to reduce ion crossover significantly, which helps improve the long-term stability of the battery.




The flow pattern of the manifold and flow channels on the reaction area was carefully studied and designed to ensure that electrolytes are introduced to the electrodes evenly across the cell and are in good contact with the electrodes. Consideration was put in place to achieve even flow by controlling the pressure drop and minimizing the shunt current. Various flow channel designs were carried out, and the graphite plates with these alternative flow channels were tested for their effects on pressure drops and cell performance. 




A new power control system (a cell phone App) was designed for remote access to the battery. Consumers can monitor battery health and energy consumption using the app. The app also communicates with a server if any concern about battery health is raised.
